body: KUGEL--Morton died November 21, 2007 at the age of 85. body: Until Jennifer McLean and two drivers from City Harvest showed up at Joe Sidoti's farm last Friday, the radishes still growing in his field were goners. The radishes would probably have been plowed under, and they certainly would not have wound up in salads in the South Bronx. But as soon as Ms. McLean saw them, big as apples and red as Christmas
title: Off City Turf, Haggling for Food

body: For much of the 20th century, New York sent its share of residents off to war, and today, in many of the state's working-class neighborhoods and towns, the armed forces are as revered as ever. But as New York's veterans march up Fifth Avenue and numerous local Main Streets today, they will barely resemble the crowds around them. Because their ranks
title: Veterans' Rolls Decline Here As Fewer Enlist and More Move

body: The Brooklyn Navy Yard will become home to a historic center as part of its expansion and redevelopment, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn said yesterday. title: NEW YORK; Brooklyn: Navy Yard Development

body: MIKE NELSON A Psychic Vacuum Essex Street Market 117 Delancey Street, at Essex Street, Lower East Side Through Oct. 28 The first major work executed in this country by the British installation wizard Mike Nelson can be found in a cavernous, unused portion of the Essex Street Market. It is an intentionally desolate labyrinth of small, low-ceilinged
title: Art in Review

body: The Brooklyn Navy Yard, one of New York City's major industrial real estate sites, is undergoing a renaissance. Since last fall, new developments totaling 1.3 million square feet have been announced for the yard, a 300-acre industrial park on the East River between the Williamsburg and Manhattan Bridges. This is in addition to the 4 million square
title: Brooklyn Navy Yard, a Roomy Haven for Industry, Once Again Is Booming

body: ECONOMIC DATA SINKS STOCKS The stock market plunged late in the afternoon, registering its biggest drop in three weeks as investors were hit by fresh worries over declining consumer confidence, falling house prices, shrinking profits on Wall Street and uncertainty about the Federal Reserve. MEDIAN INCOME EDGES UP The nation's median household
title: TODAY IN BUSINESS

body: Peggy Samuels, an amateur art historian who with her husband, Howard, wrote or edited 10 books on art and United States history, including a revealing biography of Frederic Remington, the renowned painter of the American West, died Thursday at her home in East Falmouth, Mass. She was 84. The death was announced by her daughter Amy Samuels. Mrs.
title: Peggy Samuels, 84, Biographer and Art Historian

title: HABITATS | BOERUM HILL, BROOKLYN; Earning an A in Real Estate 101

body: Architectural details like cornices, cast-iron columns, and brownstone sills and lintels have always spelled class in a city like New York. title: Fort Greene/Clinton Hill; In the Details, a Small-Town Feel

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Development For Former Navy Site

body: Two people were in critical condition last night following two hit and runs, one in Manhattan and one in Brooklyn, according to the police. title: 2 Are Critically Injured in Hit and Runs

body: That Wild Ride Under the El Q. I think the car-subway chase in ''The French Connection'' is the most exciting scene ever filmed, but I've always wondered where it took place. A. Gene Hackman's harrowing pursuit under the elevated tracks, which took five weeks to create and ran for about seven minutes on the screen, was filmed on a 30-block stretch
title: F. Y. I.

body: ONE of the high points of my childhood on Long Island -- where most buildings were as ordinary as Monopoly houses -- was driving past Endo Labs, a pharmaceutical company headquarters in Garden City made of undulating surfaces of corduroy-textured concrete. Endo was part medieval castle, part flying saucer and unlike any building I had ever seen.
title: A Road Trip Back to the Future

body: A museum review on Saturday about the U.S.S. Monitor Center in Newport News, Va., misidentified the site where the Monitor was built. It was the Continental Iron Works in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, not the Brooklyn Navy Yard. (The ship was outfitted and commissioned at the yard.)
title: Corrections

body: As sacred relics go, it doesn't seem too inspiring. In appearance, Nathaniel Hawthorne said, it ''looked like a gigantic rat-trap.'' In life, it had little more than a single day of major achievement, and in that it was less than triumphant. In death, it was even less grand, sinking into the Atlantic during a storm, not even a year after it first
title: MUSEUM REVIEW; A Celebrity Warship Gets a Hall of Fame to Call Its Own

body: An article on Wednesday about the death of a shipyard worker at the Brooklyn Navy Yard misstated the given name of a spokesman for the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration who said the accident was being investigated. He is John Chavez, not Juan.
title: Corrections

body: A shipyard worker died yesterday after falling at least 25 feet in a fuel barge at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the police said, the second fatality this month at a work site operated by GMD Shipyard Corporation. The man, Arturo Medina, 36, of Brooklyn, was climbing down a 50-foot ladder into the dry-docked barge's hull when he fell just after 10:30
title: Man Dies in Fall, Second Fatality At Brooklyn Shipyard in January

body: A man who works at an organization that collaborates with a school in Brooklyn was charged yesterday with sexually assaulting a teenage student, city school officials said. The man, Ivory Gordon, 24, of Brooklyn, was charged with rape, sex abuse and criminal sexual conduct, according to the office of Richard J. Condon, the special commissioner of
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Arrest In Rape Of Student

body: An investigation is under way into what caused a metal plate weighing thousands of pounds to fall and crush a worker to death on Saturday morning at the GMD Shipyard in the Brooklyn Navy Yard, a spokesman for the Occupational Safety and Health Administration said yesterday. ''We are conducting an investigation to determine whether any safety
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Accident Inquiry Begins

body: You can see them everywhere in the blocks near Cadman Plaza: lost tourists, brows furrowed over guidebooks, looking for that most elusive of landmarks, the Brooklyn Bridge. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; To Cross the Bridge, Job No. 1 Is to Get on It

body: Christopher G. Thomas hardly ever worked on Saturdays. It was his day to shop, do laundry and, most important, languidly pass the hours with his wife. But yesterday, needing money, Mr. Thomas reported to work as an ironworker at the GMD Shipyard in the Brooklyn Navy Yard near Fort Greene. About 10:15 a.m., witnesses said, a massive metal plate,
title: Shipyard Worker Killed by Falling Metal Plate
